title: 110_hr3463
content: The National Park Ranger School Partnership Program is established under Part D of title V of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. This program authorizes partnerships with National Park Ranger Schools. The Secretary, in cooperation with the National Park Service, may award grants to schools and educational agencies for educational programs emphasizing science, environment, math, civics, and history for students in kindergarten through grade 12. The Secretary, in cooperation with the National Park Service, may award grants to schools and educational agencies for professional development opportunities emphasizing science, environment, math, civics, and history for educators of students in kindergarten through grade 12. Grants are for a 3-year period with a maximum amount of $25,000. Eligibility requires a partnership with the National Park Service or a technology-based distance learning link to the National Park Service. Grants under this subpart are awarded on a competitive basis using criteria established jointly by the Secretary and the Director of the National Park Service. Grantees must submit a report upon completing the grant period, detailing the number of students participating in activities and their academic achievements in relevant areas. The Secretary, in coordination with the National Park Service, will assess the grant activities based on statewide student scores in math or science and other benchmarks. A report must be submitted within 3 years, detailing the number of educators involved and their professional development in relevant academic areas. The Secretary and the National Park Service will submit a report to Congress on the implementation of the program, including recommendations on its continuation or expansion. $1,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2008 for this purpose. The National Park Service is now eligible for certain educational programs under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. This includes math and science partnerships and the teaching of traditional American history. Educational service agencies, including federal agencies, can also serve as educational service providers.
